properties.description: It is a district located in the southern of the province called Victor Fajardo. Before the conflict Asquipata was an organised community with a participatory population. They had a very rich social culture as strong artisansÕ organisations, active authorities and solid wheat business connections. Asquipata also received and managed material support from international cooperation because of their strategic network in Lima, the urban capital. When the internal conflict began, villagers began to flee and the social structure began to be destroyed.

Vizcachayoc was a Shining Path storage located in almost the highest part of the Asquipata town. This site was a hut that was used as a warehouse and place to sleep and spend the night. It is said that when Asquipata was declared as a freedom area by Shining Path, it meant a controlled zone, the leftist group built small places like this to hide and stay temporarily in order to watch people.

Ccehua Ccehua was a small place near to Vizcachayoc. It is not visible at first sight because it is covered by vegetation and settled above an agricultural terrace. There are a few remains such as aligned stones that were the base of two old rooms. One was used to cook and the other to spend the night and store supplies. Here, subversives might have cooked their food and rested for short periods.

In Asquipata, following a path that only villagers knew, to the southwest and towards the low agricultural area, there is a Shining Path camp called Killirka. This is located in the middle of a forest and settled on a gorge. Killirka showcases the base of stone structures that belonged to a kitchen and benches. These benches might have been used for listening to lessons given by Shining Path members about war and Marxism. Additionally, they may have also received gun training. Killirka was a strategic site which connected with other towns by walking up and down the mountains. This is the main reason why Shining Path was known in this area as the ÔwalkersÕ, since they walked across mountains and other kind of geography instead of using cars and helicopters like the military.

Sayhuapata is located near the Asquipata town, on the southwest side. It was specifically a storage place for weapons, explosives and perhaps, for valuable material as gold. According to testimonies, when the military captured one of Shining PathÕs leaders in Asquipata, the latter told them about this cave. After the military found the cave location, they went straight to the hideout and took all the objects there.

This Shining Path site is located near to Chihuire town in Asquipata district. To get there, it is necessary to walk following the outskirts of the mountains. Sillacha is a small building formed by walls made up of stones and mortar. According to testimonies, the area next to this site was used as a training camp.

This is a town in the Asquipata district. Shining Path as military threatened villagers from Morcolla Chico during the 1980s. Because of this, the community were prohibited of trading agricultural products and animals as well as they suffered several violent attacks from both sides. In consequence, many villagers, including women and children, were assassinated extrajudicially.

On the 16 December 1983, military arrived in Morcolla Chico in a helicopter in order to capture Shining Path members. They started to shoot aimlessly and this resulted in the death of subversives as well as innocent civilians. In the middle of this shooting, a young Shining Path couple ran towards Chaucerahuaycco, a deep gorge, to avoid to be captured. Then, they jumped into the gorge, fell down and died immediately. Years later, some drought season came and people were concerned because its cultivation areas needed water. Then, villagers thought this might have happened because the subversiveÕs bodies were looking to the sky. People therefore reached out the dead bodies and turned them upside down, and coincidentally it started raining again. This is part of the cosmological believe in some Andean towns.

Jesus Arotinco was 11 years old when he was approached and used by both military and Shining Path. On the one hand, military asked him to tell them about the Shining PathÕs whereabouts. On the other hand, Shining Path comrades obligated him to speak about military with them. However, on 22 December 1983, Shining Path accused him of being a snitch, they captured and forced Jesus to walk from Morcolla Chico to Chihuire. While they walked, Jesus was mistreated, beaten and threatened. Right before they arrived to the destination, the kid was stabbed. According to a testimony, the child bled to death, then was wrapped with and old duvet and, finally, was buried in an improvised grave there. However, JesusÕ body is still missing and his family is still waiting for justice.

Ccocha (a Quechua word which means ÔlakeÕ) is a town linked to Asquipata district although it is legally part of other district (Sucre). The school in Ccocha was used as a military base wherein classrooms were adapted into warehouses for supplies and weapons as well as improvised bedrooms. Military committed abuses against this community so villagers had to move away. Currently, this town is in desolation and there are only 16 people. Although the school was opened again after the internal wat, it had to be closed because of lack of students approximately two years ago.

Lucanamarca is an emblematic well known place because of the massacre on 3 April 1983. The Shining Path members decided to attack people from Yanaccollpa, Ataccara, Llacchua, Muylacruz and Lucanamarca towns. Then 69 people, including children, women and elderly, were killed in cold blood. According to Shining PathÕs leader, Abimael Guzman, this massacre was the result of a reprisal for the death of Olegario Curitomay, a local comrade. However, other causes that have not been openly discussed yet, have been analysed by Carola Falcon’ (2012). As Lucanamarca went through a complex period of violence, this generated conflict between communities, especially between Lucanamarca and Espite (in Vilcanchos district), the neighbouring village.

A special area for the 69 victims from 3 April can be found in the south of this cemetery. These victims have been legally registered as such and also their names have been written on a monument in the middle of the main plaza in Lucanamarca. This is an emblematic cemetery that represents a hard past as the seeking of justice and reconciliation in the present.

This is a natural rock that was used as a hiding place and a warehouse by Shining Path. It lies approximately 0.5 km from the Uritupampa town, in Lucanamarca district. This rock has a concave shape with some holes in the surface. These holes were big enough for subversives to enter and stay the night.

It is located nearby Santa Rosa de Ccocha town. There is no a clear path to access Anccasccocha, so a local guide who knows the terrain, will be necessary. When arriving to Anccasccocha, the encounter of two rivers and a small lake can be seen. Even though, currently this is a natural beautiful sight, this place was a training camp during the internal war. Furthermore, the Shining Path turned caves into kitchens and spaces to stay overnight.

Manchiri is located in Carapo district. Although its geography depicts a steep surface and a difficult access it is very well populated by young individuals, compared to the aforementioned towns. In the 1980s, the community of Manchiri was under control of Shining Path. They were obligated to participate in raids against other districts. Nonetheless, some of the locals were also killed by the leftist group.

This is a cemetery located almost at the top of the town wherein victims of the internal conflict were buried. It is relevant to mention that some internal war victims found in these cemeteries are illegally buried so they still need to be officially registered by the government.

This is a mass grave located in the highest part of Carapo district, close to a lake where villagers do water harvesting. According to testimonies, this grave contains four UPs (Unidentified Person) of aggrieved villagers. It is believed that they were accused of being traitors and that is why Shining Path killed them. Furthermore, it was not easy for researchers to access Rumiwasi and because of mudflow and moisture caused by the lake, this site is in danger of disappearing.

Mamasuyana is a high hill situated in Pallca town, Sacsamarca district in which a mass grave and a war scenario have been identified. On 21 May 1983, the police and community confronted and counterattacked Shining Path members at Mamasuyana hilltop. Therefore, the mass grave belongs to aggrieved persons from that event including three Shining Path leaders and a police officer. However, it is known that the rest of subversives escaped towards Chalala cave.

Chalala is a group of caves on the side of steep and high cliffs. This place has a strategic location since from there someone is able to see Pallcca and beyond. This place was mainly used as a storage and a refuge because of its suitable features to hide in. After the Pallcca confrontation, it is said that subversives remained hidden in Chalala for at least a month.

Sancos is the main district of Huancasancos province therefore the biggest and most populated. This town has better public services and economic resources in comparison to the rest of districts previously mentioned. For example, they have the oldest and most prestigious high School, called the Andes, in the area. During the internal war, the town had only the police station that was closed most of the time, and a military base was installed on the Andes High School instead. On 10 March 1983, as a strong community, villagers willingly organised the first Summit of communities to fight subversion. Nowadays, the development has reached Sancos since business and agricultural projects are big part of their lives.

Before the internal war, the Andes school was the main educational facility of the central area in Ayacucho. This was famous before, during and after war because of its prestige. Hence young students were proud of studying there. Upon Shining PathÕs teachers arrived, they captured youngÕs attention and many of them decided to join their subversivesÕ ranks, including female students. Pupils were mostly sixteen when confronted the state with the hope of a better future influenced by Shining PathÕs speech. Unfortunately, most of them died in the battlefield. And because the police and armed force did not allow subversivesÕ families to claim the corpses, these victims have not been buried properly and some of them have not been found yet.

It was installed on 23 June 1984 as well as the main military base in Huancasancos. Prior to being a military base, it was a police station that was not enough to stop the advance of the leftist group in this province. In the middle, it can be seen an old helicopter was used in the 1980s. This institution played an important role because suspects were brought from different places like Espite town in the north in order to be interrogated and cruelly tortured.

After the 3 April massacre, villagers from Lucanamarca, Sacsamarca and Sancos went to Espite town, the northern community. They looked for perpetrators of this mass murder since the family of Shining PathÕs regional leader lived there. This group of villagers along with police officers, the latter camouflaged as civilians, walked to the north on 6 April. One of the towns they went was San Miguel where they found and captured a Shining Path member. Then, more suspects also were captured; but some of them were innocent people. Later, all together went on to the south heading to the police station in Sancos. However, some of them died or disappeared on the way.

Ccerulla was a little town connected to San Miguel. Villagers said that before the war, Ccerulla produced corn and cultivated different types of vegetables. Nonetheless, because of the conflict, locals were forced to move away and agricultural activities had to stop. In August 1983, a fight between Shining Path and villagers took place in this community which resulted in the burning of a house and the displacement of the people. Nowadays, Ccerulla has only few inhabitants who live there temporarily.

Punkuccasa was a Shining PathÕs temporary refuge located in San Miguel. On the top of a high mountain at about 4000 meters above sea level in San Miguel town, passing by agricultural lands cultivated over traditional and ancient terraces, someone is able to see Punkuccasa. From this site it was possible to control the entrance and way out of San Miguel. Because its strategical position allowed individuals to move from the south to the north. When arriving to the top, an old town at the south can be seen. This town has no connection to other communities except San Miguel. Additionally, there is a Pre-Hispanic archaeological site next to Punkuccasa refuge.

Capillalloc lies in the north border of Lucanamarca, near to the Espite town. It is an area where a mass grave was found. It is said, that this grave contains the bodies of a Shining Path member and other civilians. They presumably were killed and buried during the incursion looking for perpetrators after the 3 April massacre. To understand the grave location better, first the journey of victims had to be reconstructed. This information was given by survivors and they said that there were more victims that are still missing near this place.
